subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test private member variables?
msgSnippet: ... The problem with putting the assert in the mock is that if the mock never gets called, the assert doesn t happen and the test still passes. ... about it.
messageBody:
> >So said Dave Astels on 2003-07-25 --------------------
> >--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Peter Morgan <pmorgan@j...> wrote:
> >> On Thu, 2003-07-24 at 19:15, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >> I much prefer to query the mock object and assert whether the
> >> 'correct' thing happened in the unit test.
> >
> >Hmm.. not very object opriented. Why not tell the mock what to
> >expect, and let it figure out if it happened?
>


The problem with putting the assert in the mock is that if the mock never
gets called, the assert
doesn't happen and the test still passes.

> I shall do this from this day forward (for a while) and see how I feel
about it. Likely it's just getting used to a new habit.
>
> >Then you have a specification of the interaction in your test... not
> >just the postconditions.
> >
> >How do you test for correct call sequencing?
>

I use my own Mock object framework where I maintain a queue of expected
calls. Each mock method
invocation picks an invocation handler off the list and executes it. At the
end of the test, I assert that all
the expected mock method invocations have happened. See:
http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki?MockObjectsByDelegate
